word.definition: Adjustment of an organisms internal environment to allow it to maintain a stable equilibrium.
As a mechanism for maintaining homeostasis it is where the action of effectors counteract changes in order to maintain a stable state.
The ability of an organism to keep its body temperature within certain boundaries.
The maintenance of constant osmotic pressure through variations in water/salt concentration.
Containing nitrogen.
Water soluable and nitrogenous product produced as a result of protein metabolism (mammals).
Filtration under high hydrostatic pressure which retains large molecules.

The process by which substances that are required by the body (e.g. glucose) that have previously been removed from the blood (via ultrafilration) are reabsorbed. It occurs in the proximal convolouted tubule.
Abbreviation for Antidiuretic hormone. ADH is secreted by the posterior pituitary gland and changes the permiability of the collecting duct wall.
A gland which is located at the base of the brain and is the 'master gland' of the endocrine system.
Water created by a living organism through metabolism.
The sac which surrounds the glomerulus at the start of the nephron. It is where ultrafiltration occurs.
A thin membrane of fibrous protein that sperates an epithelium from unerlying tissue.
Chemical element with atomic number 7 - key component of amino acids, DNA, RNA etc.
Chemical element with atomic number 6 - key component of carbohydrates, lipids, DNA etc. Also used by plants in photosynthesis.
Organisms that digest their food externally before absorbing the products.
A molecule which is made of a number of nucleotides linked together to form a chain. Examples include DNA + RNA.
The decay of a body or other organic matter.
Oxidization of ammonia into nitrate or nitrite.
The reduction of nitrate into nitrogen.
Abbreviation for Adenosine triphosphate. ATP is the 'unviersal energy currency' it provides enerfy for biochemical reactions in a number of organisms.
The energy required for a reaction/procees to commence.
Abbreviation of Adenosine diphosphate. ADP is ATP less a phosphate group. Removing the phosphate group from ATP releases 30 KJ/mol of energy.
The process of adding a inorganic phosphate group to a molecule.
A protein which works as a catalyst for a biochemical reaction.
The substance on which an enzyme acts.
A monosaccharide sugar. It has several forms, alpha + beta..
A rod-shaped bacterium.
A spherical bacterium.
A bacterium with a rigid spiral structure oft found in stagnant water.

Not retaining the violet stain used in Gram's method which shows that the bacterium has very little peptidoglycan in its cell wall; though the bacteria will have an outer membrane of polyscaccharides and proteins.

Retaining the violet stain used in Gram's method which shows the bacteria has a cell wall primarily made of peptidoglycan but lacking the outer membrane of gram negative bacteria. (also often less toxic)
Peptidoglycan, also known as murein, is a polymer consisting of sugars and amino acids that forms a mesh-like cell wall.
An enzyme that catalyzes the destruction of the cell walls of gram positive bacteria (by removing a the peptidoglycan and causing lysis) that is found in tears.
Large molecules made of a lipid and polysaccharide joined by a covalent bond that are found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria.
(referring to technique) Techniques that aim to ensure the complete exclusion of harmful micro-organisms.
A group of bacteria grown from a single cell on a culture medium.
A microorganism that can cause disease.
Cultivation of microorganisms in an artificial medium containing nutrients.
To undergo the chemical breakdown of a substance by microorganisms e.g bacteria, yeast.
An antibiotic group produced naturally by some blue moulds.
Organic compound that is not directly involved in the normal growth and development of an organism.
Things that causes a physiological response.
Central Nervous System
A cell/s that acts in response to a stimulus.
A cell capable of responding to stimulus and transmiting a signal to a sensory nerve.
An action that is performed without conscious thought.
A tiny aquatic invertebrate with a stalk-like tubular body and a ring of tentacles around the mouth. (of same phyla as jellyfish)
A neuron which is responsible for converting external stimuli into corresponding internal stimuli.
A neuron which carries signals from the spinal cord to the muscles in order to produce movement.
A neuron that forms a connection between other neurons.
A short-lasting event in which the electrical membrane potential of a cell rapidly rises and falls.
To have lost polarity.
A junction between two nerve cells with a minute gap across which impulses pass by diffusion of a neurotransmitter. In humans this neurotransmitter is acetylcholine.
Response of an organism to changes in the relative length of light and dark periods (day length).
The time each day during which an organism receives light. (equal to day length)
A pigment that plants use to detect light. It is sensitive to light in the red and far-red region of the visible spectrum.
The ground state of phytochrome in which red light is strongly absorbed.
State of phytochrome in which far-red (fr) light is absorbed in preference to red light.
Plants which flower when the day lengths are less than their critical photoperiod.
Plants which flower when the day length exceeds their critical photoperiod.
Plants which do not initiate flowering based on photoperiodism at all.
A process used by plants and other autotrophic organisms to convert light energy into chemical energy in the form of ATP.
The first stage of photosynthesis by which plants capture and store energy from sunlight. In this process, light energy is transferred to energy-carrying molecules ATP and NADPH.
The part of photosynthesis referred to as the calvin cycle which occurs in the stroma through which carbon dioxide (or alternatives) is converted to glucose.

Theodor Engelmann carried out an 1882 experiment measured the effects of different colors of light on photosynthetic activity and showed that the conversion of light energy to chemical energy took place in the chloroplast.
(in terms of photosyntehsis) The action spectrum shows the rate of photosynthesis at different wavelengths.
(in terms of photosyntehsis) The absorption spectrum shows how strongly the pigments absorb at different wavelengths.
Chemical compounds which reflect only certain wavelengths of visible light.
Greenish pigments which contain a porphyrin ring.
Red, orange, or yellow pigments, and include the familiar compound carotene. They are accessory pigments because they must pass their absorbed energy to chlorophyll.
A carotenoid pigment that gives carrots their colour.
Yellow pigments that form one of two major divisions of the carotenoid group.
Accessory pigments are light-absorbing compounds that transfer energy to/work with chlorophyll a and have different absorption sepctra.
The production of ATP using the energy of sunlight.
The movement of organisms into a region to which they are not native.
The movement of organisms from a region to which they are native.
The first stage of bacterial growth in which adapt themselves to growth conditions.
The secind stage of bacterial growth in which the number of new bacteria appearing per unit time is proportional to the present population.
Third phse of bacterial growth in which growth rate and death rate are equal.
Final phase of bacterial growth in which bacteria run out of nutrients and die.
A factor affecting a population which has a varying affect based on the population size e.g. water supply
A factor affecting the size of population which does not have a varying affect based on the population size e.g. weather, natural disaster.
A substance or substances used for destroying organisms which are harmful to crops or animals.
The ability not to be affected by something in an adverse manner.
The first step in respiration which produces two 3C pyruvate molecules through the removal of phosphate groups from glucose. This step reduces 2 NAD and produces 2 ATP.
The second step in respiration in which pyruvate is converted to acetyl-CoA producing C02 and a molecule of NADH.
The sequence of reactions by which most living cells generate energy during the process of aerobic respiration. Produces 3NADH, 1FADH and 1 ATP (double for each glucose).
Respiration step in which electrons are passed along a chain through a series of redox reactions in which they lose energy to produce a concentration gradient.
The removal of a carboxyl group which releases carbon dioxide.
The removal of hydrogen from a molecule as H2.
Adenosine triphosphate. The universal energy currency.
Adenosine diphosphate. Can be made into ATP though the adition of a phosphate group (phosphorylation) and when ATP loses a phosphate group to form ADP 30.5 kJ/mol of energy is released.
An electron acceptor and carrier that is reduced to NADH an gives up its electrons to the electron transport chain.
An electron carrier in respiration which is reduced to FADH2 it only contributes to 2 ATP as it has less energy, passing its electrons to a later point in the electron transport chain.
An organic acid produced in glycolysis which is decarbocylated by Acetyl-CoA so the carbon can be used in the Krebs cycle. Can also ferment to produce lactic acid when oxygen is not availiable.
acetyl coenzyme A. The main function of A-CoA is to convey the carbon atoms within the acetyl group to the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle) to be oxidized for energy production.
Oxygen is the final elextron acceptor in respiration.
The movement of ions across a selectively permeable membrane.
A difference in concentration of solutes between two regions.
